thread.title: Telstra mobile and landline down after Sydney exchange fire | Daily Telegraph
thread.title_full: Telstra mobile and landline down after Sydney exchange fire | Daily Telegraph

author: Rod Chester
title: Telstra mobile and landline down after Sydney exchange fire | Daily Telegraph
text:
TELSTRA was forced to shut down its texting services after text messages started misdirecting to random numbers following a national network meltdown.
Businesses across the country were brought to a halt, train lines were shut down in New South Wales and flights were delayed after a fire in a Sydney exchange sparked a national Telstra outage.
Telstra was forced to shut down text messaging, keeping messages in a holding pattern to be sent later after many customers reported being inundated with texts from strangers while the text messages they sent went missing.
Telstra CEO Andy Penn apologised for the network outage and called the misdirected messages “extraordinarily unusual”,
“I’ve never known that to happen before,” he said.
“Some SMS messages were corrupted, which resulted in potentially some of those going to the incorrect address.
“To safeguard our customers’ privacy, we closed the sms network down until we could reroute that and ensure the integrity of the messages.
“Obviously it’s very disappointing for our customers.
“You’ve got to take into account this is one of the major exchanges in the country.”
Mr Penn said there were no plans to offer customers widespread compensation such as the “free data” days offered after the network meltdowns last year.
“If individual customers have a particular circumstance they need to raise with us then they obviously should contact us.”
Telstra announced at 5.40 AEDT that text messages were restored and services would be rolled out progressively.
Excellent. @Telstra delivering my texts to random numbers instead of the people I sent them to. Awesome stuff.
— Crankynick (@crankynick) February 2, 2017 #Telstra my dad is receiving text messages from people he doesn't know! What's happening?
— Blastmedia (@BlastmediaAu) February 2, 2017 From unkn number, @Telstra outage causing some curious crossed wires. I hope this person gets the trifle they crave in time for tomorrow... pic.twitter.com/JhRzT7XKg1
— Anna Riddell (@a_r_riddell) February 2, 2017 #HunterLine No service due to an external telecommunications fault affecting train operating systems. Bus companies contacted.
— NSW TrainLink North (@TrainLinkNorth) February 2, 2017 Telstra customers took to social media to complain about how the fire in one exchange could impact the rest of the country, with Jetstar announcing nine planes had been delayed because of the network chaos as staff were forced to revert to manual check in.
LIVE TRAIN REPORTS
LIVE TRAFFIC REPORTS
Brought to you by Live Traffic NSW | map view
The Hunter Line in New South Wales was shut down as a result of the network failure, with customers forced to switch to buses and warned to prepare for long delays on the way home.
Telstra announced in a tweet about lunch time that there had been a fire in an exchange “impacting some mobile and fixed services”.
A fire at one of our exchanges is impacting some mobile and fixed services. We're working to resolve ASAP. Thanks for your patience.
— Telstra (@Telstra) February 2, 2017 Some flights disrupted due to @Telstra outage. 9 AU flights delayed ~45mins; check-in for some flights paused; some ports manual check-in.
— Jetstar Airways (@JetstarAirways) February 2, 2017 A further tweet confirmed the fire was in Chatswood, Sydney, and it had damaged power equipment.
Telstra tweeted about 3pm that services were starting to be restored, several hours after the first reports of the network problems.
The Aussie Outages site reported 5077 complaints of network problems, with customers in states across Australia reporting problems.
Many Telstra customers took to social media to complain about how the network outage was impacting their business.
media_camera A notice sent out from the CFA regarding the incident at the Telstra exchange. Picture: Facebook
“Cannot call or receive calls from a mobile — great situation for a sales rep,” said Steve, of Boronia, Victoria.
“My mobile can receive text messages but I cannot call Telstra or call out. My land line is also dead. What is happening. This is my business phone and I’m cut off!” Sarah of York, Western Australia said.
Telstra also reported outages with NBN services for customers in NSW although it was not clear if that was linked to the Chatswood fire.
Congrats Telstra. Made it one month of 2017 before an outage. #telstra
— Josh (@JFlinders17) February 2, 2017 A fire at @Telstra 's #Chatswood Exchange affects Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Brisbane (and the NBN). Security issue? #auspol #TUSO
— John Townsend (@jtwnz) February 2, 2017 #Telstra No backup route to bypass Chatswood Exchange for mobile services!! Bad form Telstra, bad form.
— Dave Murray (@dclnmurray) February 2, 2017 Telstra released a statement about 2.30pm saying the fire had been contained but that damage had been caused to power infrastructure.
“As a result a number of customers are experiencing loss of service,” the statement said.
“Our technicians are currently completing a full assessment of the impact.”
The national problem follows a string of network meltdowns in 2016, which caused Telstra to announce a $50 million plan to build a more robust network and add more levels of redundancy that would help avoid a national meltdown following a single problem.
Speaking to News Corp Australia late last year, Telstra CEO Andy Penn said he could not guarantee the network would never have another meltdown.
“What I can guarantee though is that its absolutely got our full attention and backed up with a significant amount of investment, both in terms of addressing the issues we’ve identified but also building the resiliency and redundancy in the future,” he said.
Telstra was not the only one left red-faced after technical difficulties today. The ATO website was also down for several hours, with the ATO blaming the crash again on the problematic Hewlett-Packard Enterprise hardware system that suffered a major failure in December.
Originally published as ‘I’ve never known that to happen before’
